messages: 138522876388ded1159c4e57cebbe357 (09:37): thanks see you.

7570592ee20afa32751193360b701a4b (09:57): Hi, i'm using mysql as a stats backend, my table has approx 170 million rows and each row is about 40 bytes wide.  I have a relatively beefy system  ( dual opterons, 8G ram ) and am running mysql 4.1 using the Innodb engine.  Queries typically take 5 to 6 hours to run is this typical or is there something I am missing?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:08): oremj: That's not enough detail.  That's like saying I have a program that takes 10 miuntes to run.  I this normal?
7570592ee20afa32751193360b701a4b (10:09): Xgc: what information would help you?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:09): oremj: If it determines the true meaning of life, that's probably good.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:09): oremj: Something more then Zero.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:09): oremj: Do you have a particular query in mind?
7570592ee20afa32751193360b701a4b (10:10): let me grab an example
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:10): does mysql allow me to set the default value of a varbinary to NUL?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:10): 1 hour for that would be excessive.
7570592ee20afa32751193360b701a4b (10:11): SELECT DATE(firstsaw) as day, count(*) as cnt
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:13): oremj: Hard to tell without seeing the distribution of data.  It could be fairly expensive.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:15): oremj: It's probably i/o bound.  How many records per day (average)?
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:15): anybody know?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:15): DavidMJ: Did you try it?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:16): DavidMJ: You could have tested it several times already.
7570592ee20afa32751193360b701a4b (10:16): probably a 500k to a million a day
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:16): Xgc: my experiment is not conclusive
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:16): thus, i seek help
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:16): DavidMJ: What did the manual say?
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:16): nothing from what i could determine
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:17): DavidMJ: What were the results of your tests?
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:17): ambigous, I did not know if it was truely returning NUL or not
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:18): DavidMJ: Did you mean NULL or 0 (nul)?
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:18): NUL
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:18): ascii code 0
87919d6a5f11a6a833252caa350f556f (10:25): hello @all :-) does somebody know why the mysql-server5.0.22 Package in Ubuntu dapper which apt-get installs is without InnoDB and how to activate it ? :-)
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:27): Xgc: ?
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:28): nevermind
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:29): DavidMJ: If earlier version are a problem for you, 5.0.15 and beyond probably has the behavior you need.
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:29): I went with DEFAULT 0x00
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:29): DavidMJ: 0 would be sufficient.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:30): DavidMJ: I'm still not sure why you had a tough time testing this.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:31): DavidMJ: and the documentation is fairly clear.
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:31): nor do I
87919d6a5f11a6a833252caa350f556f (10:31): hi can somebody help me ? how can i activate innoDB storage ? :-)
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:31): http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/binary-varbinary.html
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:31): that says not a word regarding NUL values as default
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:31): perhaps you found a different piece of documentation?
e4ff7fb2ca4ab89d51f13720d16ab234 (10:32): Cyball: as in change a table to use InnoDB, or actually enable the InnoDB engine within mysqld?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:32): DavidMJ: Yes. 0 or '\0' is the value you are looking for.
0e287b9ab95fd54bd6de2fd5db27a500 (10:32): can i also use the 0x00 notation?
